title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
A greater proportion of married mixed-gender couples pool money than married same-gender couples








Married mixed-gender couples are more likely to report they ‘put all of their money together’ compared with married same-gender couples.
Brings up some questions about potential differences in stability and quality of same and mixed gender couples.


doi: 10.1177/23780231221138719

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Research Questions



Is the gap in income pooling accounted for by variation in demographic characteristics?

Do the associations between pooling and relationship stability and quality vary by the gender composition of the couple?




<click>
First RQ: [read it]
Descriptive statistics show men partnered with men are less likely to be living with a child.
Pooling is more common with a breadwinner/homemaker work family arrangements, which might vary by couple-type. Relative earnings differences is also gendered, which might have implications.
<click>
Second RQ [read it]
Divisions of housework/childcare are different for same-gender couples than mixed-gender.
Meanings of relationship traits are also different at times.
Wondering if the same is true about financial integration.

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Relationship Quality Scales



Instability



feeling trapped

think will eventually breakup

thought relationship is in trouble



Dissatisfaction



happiness with relationship

warm and comfortable relationship

relationship is rewarding

relationship satisfaction



Negativity


little arguments escalated

partner criticism

partner viewed words or actions negatively

one of us withdrew when argued





Constructed 3 relationship scales.
Instability test if stability is different based on subjective measures compared with marital status.
2 scales of relationships quality: Dissatisfaction Negativity
The test of the interitem correlations for each of the three scales showed a Cronbach’s α level greater than .82.

Logistic regression results show same-gender couples remain less likely than mixed-gender couples to report full financial pooling, even after adjusting for demographic characteristics, relationship stability, and relationship quality scales. Following figures show predicted probabilities of pooling from interaction effects from these full models (all controls).


N = 3,348 * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001
adjusted for demographic characteristics, relationship stability, and relationship quality scales

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Married women-women couples less likely to pool all money than mixed-gender couples







As shown in this figure, woman-woman married couples are less likely than mixed-gender couples to pool all finances, whereas cohabiting couples of all types are less likely to pool all finances.

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Take-away statement here







As shown in this figure…

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Women-women couples less likely to pool all money than mixed-gender couples

at average levels of __________






Similar pattern emerges when we look at pooling and average levels of instability, dissatisfaction, and negativity.
Woman-woman couples remained less likely than mixed-gender couples to report full financial pooling.
So far, this is a story of differences in intercepts.
Let’s take a look at variation in slopes.

title: Financial Integration:  Same-gender and  Mixed-gender Couples
text:
Variation in probability of pooling by couple-type and relationship scales







Not too surprising, for all couples, the odds of pooling money were significantly lower with greater instability.
The same pattern is present for the relationship dissatisfaction scale, with one exception.
Among men partnered with men, higher levels of dissatisfaction were associated with greater odds of pooling money.
Negativity and pooling money showed the opposite pattern for all couple types. Negativity was positively associated for all couple-types.
Does this say something about the directionality?
